title:
Bounds on the complex viscoelasticity for surface waves on ice-covered
  seas
authors: C. Sampson, D. Hallman, N. B. Murphy, E. Cherkaev, K. M. Golden
abstract:
Oceanic wave propagation through Earth's sea ice covers is a critical
component of accurate ice and climate modeling. Continuum models of the polar
ocean surface layer are characterized rheologically by the effective complex
viscoelasticity of the composite of ice floes and sea water. Here we present
the first rigorous theory of this parameter, and distill its dependence on
mixture geometry into the spectral properties of a self-adjoint operator
analogous to the Hamiltonian in quantum physics. Bounds for the complex
viscoelasticity are obtained from the sea ice concentration and the contrast
between the elastic and viscous properties of the ice and water/slush
constituents. We find that several published wave attenuation datasets in both
laboratory and field settings fall well within the bounds for specific contrast
values of the ice/ocean composite.
